channel.title: Comments on: How To Script Out The Whole Database In SQL Server 2005 and SQL Server 2008
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: TSQLDeveloper
item.dc:creator: TSQLDeveloper
item.content:encoded:
Hi Denis,
With SQl2008 users can script data as well which is a great easiness for developers.

Have a look at :
http://www.kodyaz.com/articles/sql-server-script-data-with-generate-script-wizard.aspx

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Nate, You can also see an example of SMO in action here
/index.php/DataMgmt/DBAdmin/MSSQLServerAdmin/smo-script-index-and-fk-s-on-a-database

What Denis showed is really a task that would take a bit of effort in development in SMO though. I recommend and perform the same types of automated scripts like you are thinking of on specific objects and manually make script backups with exactly the same steps Denis shows. Developing that much in SMO is very time consuming but if you did it, might be worth it in the long run and future usage

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Nate, you can use Server Management Objects (SMO) to script it out also (that is what the GUI uses behind the scenes anyway)
item.content:encoded: Nate, you can use Server Management Objects (SMO) to script it out also (that is what the GUI uses behind the scenes anyway)

item.title: By: Nate
item.dc:creator: Nate
item.description: Thanks for the tip! Do you know if this can be scripted or if it has to be done through the SQL Management Studio GUI?
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the tip! Do you know if this can be scripted or if it has to be done through the SQL Management Studio GUI?
